Title:
On the recognition of Gymnosphaera as a distinct genus in
Cyatheaceae
Keywords:
chloroplast DNA sequences; new combinations; phylogeny;
scaly tree ferns; taxonomy
Abstract:
The Cyatheaceae is a big family, containing over 600
species of scaly tree ferns. Its subdivision in taxonomy has troubled
pteridologists for more than one century. Recent molecular analyses have
revealed four monophyletic groups (Alsophila, Cyathea, Gymnosphaera, and
Sphaeropteris) within this family. However, one of the four groups,
Gymnosphaera, was still submerged in Alsophila in a modern
classification proposed by the Pteridophyte Phylogeny Group probably
because Gymnosphaera was phylogenetically underrepresented in previous
studies. In this study we add the sampling of Gymnosphaera from its main
distribution area (SE Asia) and conduct phylogenetic analyses of
datasets containing individual or combined five cpDNA regions (rbcL,
rbcL-accD, rbcL-atpB, trnG-trnR, and trnL-trnF) of 140 ingroups in three
methods (maximum parsimony, maximum likelihood, and Bayesian inference).
The result is congruent with previous studies, consistently resolving
scaly tree ferns as four well-supported clades with Sphaeropteris sister
to the other three, and shows a new probability on the relationships
between Alsophila, Cyathea, and Gymnosphaera, i.e., Alsophila is sister
to Gymnosphaera and then together as sister to Cyathea. As well
supported to be monophyletic by both molecular and morphological
characters, Gymnosphaera is reinstated here, with a minor emendation in
circumscription, as a separate genus. To facilitate the application of
speciesÂ’ names and future revision, we provide a checklist of 45 extant
taxa now known in Gymnosphaera with information of nomenclatural types
and general distributions; among them 26 are new combinations.
